review: I wholeheartedly recommend Black Myth: Wukong to any fan of Souls-like games. This title has become a true addiction for me. While some boss encounters have tested my patience, I recognize that it's more a matter of improving my own skill through trial and error. The game is a masterful work of art, inspired by the classic Chinese novel Journey to the West, yet telling the story in its own unique and captivating way. Every scene, every battle, and every chapter is presented with such stunning visual spectacle that it's impossible not to be drawn in by its beauty. Rich in content, Black Myth: Wukong offers a deeply immersive experience, and with the anticipated DLC on the horizon, I’m eagerly looking forward to diving back in for more challenges and even greater adventures!

review: 2022 Fantastic game that suffers from open world syndrome of having quantity over quality with all the mini-dungeons in the game (at least the loot is good). The quests are all pretty interesting in their own ways and 9 times out of 10 it is fairly rewarding to follow the questlines. Boss fights are for the most part easier than the previous souls games, however in some cases they can be more difficult, especially if you don't use the ash summons (they intend and definitely encourage you to use them however).Enemy reuse is really bad in this game, ranging from simply reusing enemies from previous games to reusing main story big bads (with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ moveset) in random dungeons and reusing the enemies (mini-bosses) which are new to this game except now there's two, oh and now there's three of them, and oh there he is again, and again, and again, now he's a common enemy. The horse is also too strong and honestly doesn't add much to the game besides allowing you to platform higher I guess.In any case, the game is still fun if you like souls games, and this is exactly that, just more souls except with a different name and a much bigger (for better or for worse) scale. The new weapons and move sets are neat and they have also added a huge amount of sorceries as well as weapon arts that you can swap around.

review: 2022 Just finished a Cathay campaign. Two strong impressions: 1. Siege battles feel much more fun because of the new multi-layer settlements maps and supply mechanic to build defense structures. 2. Quest battles are also very enjoyable, having to capture multiple victory points and hold them against enemies waves, meanwhile you have supply points to build defense structure, call in reinforcements, and buff/heal units mid-battle. Downside is that these battles are quite long now.The new siege battles are definitely more fun than before if you are defending. You can build defense structures like towers, traps, and barricades. And the new settlements map are huge and complex with multi-layer pathways and many interesting choke points. This opens up many interesting strategies to turn defeats into heroic victories. I was able to win many outnumbered defense battles by holding crucial choke points and maneuver my army through multiple lines of defenses to wear enemies down. Cathay crossbows felt so strong when you have them positioned on higher grounds and having your melee units hold the enemies down. The downsides are these battles are sometimes very long (because of how big the new maps are), and attackers do feel harder to play (if you don't take supply point, the defenders can constantly build towers, traps, and etc.).The quest battles are also more interesting now. You have to capture several locations sequentially and after each capture, you have 45 sec to build defenses and layout your army against a coming enemy wave. These battles are super fun because you need to play as both attacker and defender--you capture points from enemies and then defend them against them who are trying to take them back. You can also call in reinforcements, heal, restock, or buff your units mid-battle using supply points which are passively generated. The maps are also huge, with interesting terrains and choke points where you can leverage to either hold points or push through enemy defenses. The final battle also have interesting mechanics: (XD Annoying or Fun very subjective) 1. Constant spawning of enemy troops behind you after taking first points. Forcing you to take next victory point quickly while hold up against enemies chasing behind you. 2. Random enemy teleport onto final victory point(soulgrinders into the middle of your army). This scared me so hard since these giant , nonstoppable monstrous machines just started spawning and running through my crossbows at the end. Downside is still the same: The battles can feel long--easily 30+ min.As for optimization, I honestly feel it is similar to Total War Warhammer II, occasional FPS drops, especially on the campaign . I did not experience anything major that stopped me from playing it. The only bug I encounter was that a few of the rifts I closed somehow reopened after I reloaded the save file the next day. I was able to enjoying the game, and I don't really expect any more optimization improvement. As long as it runs fine as Warhammer II, and whenever Mortal Empire (whatever you call it, the aggregation of Warhammer I, II, III) come out, the game still runs the same, I am totally fine with the current state of optimization.

review: 2023 First of all, if you enjoy strategy games, fantasy games or Warhammer or Total War titles in general, you are almost sure to enjoy this game too. You can easily sink hundreds of hours into Total War Warhammer 3, especially if you buy the right additional content. I have, in all three games combined, around 2000 hours myself.However I cannot with good conscience recommend this dumpster fire of a game unless you can find absolutely no other games to enjoy. It is unfortunately rotten to its core and I don't see any way for the developers to fix it. I sincerely hope future games will do a better job, but this one does not deserve your time. Why, you ask? Well, both sides of the gameplay are just so glaringly inadequate. First, this game is all about capturing settlements with your armies. That constitutes 90% of your campaign goals, that is how you grow your empire and make more money etc. So battles using said armies and for said settlements should probably be the best feature of the game... Right? WRONG! Some of the battles are so bad that even trying to write about them right now makes me furious. The variety in battles is amazing, but that causes the poorly programmed AI armies to flounder more often than not. In field battles, the enemy units will try to repeatedly get into new formations, neither defending against your incursions nor advancing on you. It is somehow less competent in higher battle difficulties. Once you get the hang of it, more often than not, you can destroy whole armies of elite troops with only a couple of units of your own. As for the battles taking place in settlements... I don't think I could do justice to how awful the AI becomes. If you don't take my word for it, I suggest you watch some gameplay online that demonstrates this debaucle; there are plenty of such videos and streams. The layout of the settlements also boggles the mind. Every infantry unit features magically appearing ladders aptly dubbed by the community "butt ladders," making the walls trivial, the design of which are already pretty senseless by themselves. Inside the settlements you have fixed spots where you can build barricades and towers using some vague resource that you accumulate over time. The location of those defenses can be absolutely insane (like towers blocked by buildings on all sides, rendering them useless), the pathfinding would have been considered terrible even in a game 10 years old, and the so called victory points ... Oh my god, it is just so bad. SO BAD. Even the simplest tower defense flash game has better design than these battles - which are not even supposed to be like tower defense battles! They are supposed to reflect real siege battles in a reasonable fashion. They. Just. Don't. These battles were actually so badly received by the community that one update removed most settlement battles and replaced them with field battles. The campaign management is also laughably stupid. Campaign in Total War games has never been on par with other major turn based strategy titles like Civilization, of course, because this series also supposed to feature amazing real time battles. But in the Warhammer series, it is dumbed down lower than imaginable. Though some mechanics introduced in the overpriced paid DLCs are very interesting, all the basic features are largely unimaginative and lazy. Call me crazy, but I think such an essential part of a 60-dollar strategy game should be at least halfway decent without having to pay for any additional content. Diplomacy is mostly a joke; only one deal in a hundred that you make requires any strategical thinking. It is admittedly better in TWW3 than in TWW1 and 2, but not because it is now of a higher quality, but because you are now forced to waste less time on it thanks to quick diplomacy and auto-balance options. Most of the races from the first and second games either have not had updates to adjust them to the third game or said updates do not function properly: It is clear from the lackluster skill lines of older characters, missing features in the mechanics, incompatible and insufficient adjustments to the new diplomacy options and other interactions between factions etc. that no real thought has been put into how these factions should play together in the new game. It is like comparing a well made article of clothing to one with weird patches all over it; you can clearly see that the patches don't belong, which makes the cloting seem very cheap and unattractive. Not to mention that many of the updates the game receives just do not work. There have been dozens of critical issues that the developers claimed to have fixed in a patch, which turned out to be blatant lies, like FIVE TIMES IN A ROW. I refuse to believe that they do any testing before releasing these updates. And there remains a buttload of important problems that they are yet to even acknowledge. Again, you will probably have fun in this game despite all these issues (and more). Of course, you will likely get bored and fatigued by your campaign by the mid game and either start a new campaign before you get to the good stuff or stop playing for a while. That is what happens to most players.

review: Campaign:Great Cinematic experience, better with friends, very cool.Only low point I can think of are the "Rats" section of the 2nd mission and some downtime sections from the "Cave" mission.PvP:It's ok, a bit death-bally and significantly less emphasis on Melee in my short experience with it.I didn't have much interest in it before and quickly lost interest in it, so I haven't played a lot of rounds nor grind each classes to unlock their other, more interesting weapons.(Co-)Operations:Only having 6 missions on launch is terrible, -Tide games and World War Z had more on launch in the past and needed more content.It is early, but the balance seemed all over the place. At the higher difficulties, there are fewer resources and sometimes placement of Ammo Crates, it felt similar to the tactical survival experience of Back 4 Blood, World War Z, and maybe like playing Remnant 2 with a non-S/ A-Tier build but instead using a sub-optimal life-leech build. Regardless of the difficulty, missions have RNG aspects to it such as the mid-level events requiring 1-6 sub-objectives to complete.You have to ration your ammo in specific parts of certain missions and try to use the environment and equipment you find as optimally as possible (explosive barrels, explosive flowers, and level gimmicks such as the fire wall at the end of the first mission).Enemies becomes bullet spongy at higher difficulties and are more numerous, with less resources spawning, and Medicae Stims healing less HP. Different weapon types seem to have different effectiveness vs specific enemies. Running away to the next airlock/ elevator to despawn enemies behind you is cheesy but effective.Perk and class balance seemed to be all over the place, but I need to play more to be sure, and there seems to be some bugs or hidden effects (Bulwark fully-healing after using Loadout change pods and their banner phasing through the lift in a mission). Examples for balance stuff: - Certain classes have ammo generation perks later on in their class (or weapon perk line) which seems to be a mandatory pick compared to the other options; - Bulwark's Level 8 perk restores max contested health for squadmates in the AoE, allowing you to partially/ fully heal when combined with an enemy execution/ finisher, and the level 23 perk shares this with squadmates anywhere, which substantially reduces the need for healing items (and again, seems like a mandatory pick compared to the other options); - Weapons with high damage per shot that can hit multiple enemies can heal past contested health (e.g. Melta Rifle, Las Fusil, etc).Also you use the same currency to buy weapons, class perks, and Space Marine Chapter Customization and you always feel poor while progressing initially, with some classes having more expensive weapons (e.g. Assault). You also need to grind each class and weapons types.Additionally, trying to get an Armory Data to unlock the next tier of weapons for the first time will be tougher than usual as you need to play the higher tier with previous tier weapons.

review: One must imagine Skarbrand happy. So where to begin? Back in 2014-2015 this got revealed, this being Total War: Warhammer, and it was a step in a new direction for Total War albeit one that wasn't that unusual since there have been Warhammer mods for other Total War games. And with Warhammer its frequently about huge armies clashing, even in 40K, and whilst you may not have 100,000 individual units, it still fit. However it was a massively risky move since it was a departure from historical Total War games.Yet it worked.Whilst TWW is still rough in some ways, I know it can be a lot of times for too arcade-y for me, I keep coming back and playing it. I attribute this to the fact that its weakness is also its strength, the arcadey-ness. I also attribute this to the fact that its practically, currently, the best Warhammer RTS game that actually has to do with Fantasy Battles, not even the Old World, which is Fantasy Battles and the setting, but like WHFB (Warhammer Fantasy Battles) as it WAS before Age of Sigmar (very controversial and something I'm still not in love with).If you can stomach the DLC list, you have access to multitudes of characters that shone in the spotlight before 40K became the big money maker, characters that still aren't in Age of Sigmar or radically different to the point many feel unfitting. That's the next best part about this game, its incredibly diverse. You have access to factions that were never on the tabletop or lore only. Norsca as a whole was split up between various Chaos factions, Vampire Coast didn't exist, it was Dreadfleet and lore characters at best, Cathay never had anything beyond being this mysterious land with like one or two units in the Third Edition of all things.All 3 are playable as their own faction.There's characters you can play that didn't exist as of the time period (2522 IC), such as Boris Ursus who died and Repanse who died 500 years before. But with a little lore-wise handwave, they're back, and incredible to play. There's even characters who were lore only, no table top figure, who you can utilize as commander/Legendary Lord, such as Nakai of the Lizardmen, he was practically only in books and the Lizardmen rule books.These little flavors of Warhammer have me overjoyed to be fair, and sure many lords don't always land, such as Tretch Craventail who may as well just exist but CA added him because he had a mini and there wasn't much else who wasn't already getting planed to be added, but that's fun, not everything is going to be a Major W, some have to be Minor Ws.The battles are of course a huge highlight. I want to say every form of fighting in a Total War game has been sufficiently different from the others in the franchise. Between the ranged formations of Empire and Napoleon to the vast field battles of Shogun 2 that seem to recreate samurai movies, what Warhammer offers is just a lot of magic and various armies clashing, of course, this lacks in other Total War games, and I don't mean that in a snide way I mean that in a "Theres a whole new layer of strategy added." When I say various armies clashing too, think of the Skaven who are basically a "Mad Science" faction, vs Bretonnia, who is very much this Medieval era "Legends of King Arthur" faction and all the tech progress that comes with it. It comes down to strategy and tactics to beat an enemy that by all accounts trumps the Bretonnians because the Skaven just have guns.It goes without saying that of course in other total war games, the tech level was "the same", sans for maybe some drastic differences in some real world groups at the time.The best part of the game though is you don't need to know anything about Warhammer. You'll find out from in game stuff if anything. But you don't need to know anything at all you can go into this blind and learn your way from there. Sans the DLC list, this is a very accessible game for anyone.And for a nerd like me, this is an oasis in a franchise thats become Space Marines and Sigmarines, and that's where I believe a lot of love stems from, not just enjoyment of the Total War franchise.

review: 2022 I'm going to start with the cons:* Honestly, the Realms of Chaos campaign took the fun out of the game. I don't enjoy the race and demon rifts. I'd prefer other objectives, like the newer factions in TWW2 got. I never played that one's vortex race much either.* Everything seems bare bones and the things I was excited for pre-release ended up being boring and draining (Minor settlement sieges, chaos realms, and massive battles in those realms).* I'm extremely disappointed that CA and GW have something against including Araby, even though it was much requested by many people in WH2 and is still often requested. It has lore, characters, and land in the game, would sell like hotcakes, and has a different aesthetic from all the current races. And yet, they won't bring it to the game for some unknown reason.The pros:* I love Warhammer and Total War. This series is a match made in heaven and my most played game series ever.* I love the new factions here (Ogre Kingdoms were my most desired faction). I love Kislev, and like the idea of Cathay, even though they are pretty bare bones in roster. Every faction feels a unique from the others in campaign play and aesthetics.* It has potential. We got some new minor races and I hope we get more (Araby, Southern Realms, Ind, Khuresh, etc.)I don't recommend the game in its current state. Maybe try back in a year or so, after the large map is released and the factions are more fleshed out.

review: 2022 I haven't yet completed the game, but I'm posting a review now because people need to know.The game itself is great but has issues not related to gameplay which degrade the experience so much that I honestly can't recommend this in it's current state.This unlike earlier From Software games, uses EasyAntiCheat which has been causing issues for many players, including myself. More often than not, the EAC popup shows but after that the game window never shows up. The only somewhat reliable workaround is to delete the EasyAntiCheat folder from inside the game's files (and the game's compatdata directory if using Linux) and then verifying the game's local files. Steam will then re-download the correct EAC files and the game should be able to launch.Other users have been experiencing different problems with EAC, such as crashes, getting stuck at a white/black screen and "inappropriate activity detected" errors etc without any good reason.If you are able to get the game started, you're faced with the second major issue, performance.Afaik, this is an issue on the PC version only, but nevertheless a major issue which needs to be fixed.Even on high-end hardware, the game fails to maintain a steady 60fps, especially in open areas. Sometimes the framerate drops down to 20-30fps in the worst cases. Only in some closed areas a steady 60fps is possible currently.This game deserves a thumbs up, but I can't give it before these issues are solved...EDIT: Seems like my savefile just got deleted. When I started the game I was only presented with a "NEW GAME" option in the main menu. No "CONTINUE" or "LOAD GAME" option in sight. So apparently that's a thing too...EDIT 2: Most of the game's performance issues have been solved, but not all and EAC is still causing the same problems as before.

review: Rise, Son of Guilliman After finishing the campaign I just had to write a review to get my thoughts down on paper, this review will contain no spoilers for the story, but will talk about themes, gameplay and performance. Together of course with an overall impression, to start things off. Space Marine 2 exceeded my expectations by a significant margin, this game is really, really fun to play. I've seen some other reviews talking about how the combat system is "unforgiving", but I can only say that I disagree. The fast paces melee / ranged blend is really satisfying once you figure out what works for you. I played the game on the second to highest difficulty for my first run so far, I had to adjust in the beginning but once I got over the hurdle, quite frankly I just saw myself improving and getting better at managing the fights. To an extent fights in this game feel reminiscent of those from DOOM, specifically Eternal. Every fight is a puzzle that you need to think creatively to solve together with staying on top of incoming attacks and positioning. Complaints about the AI are valid, but I didn't notice much in terms of them getting in the way of me having fun. Performance wise, I'm running on a fairly old rig, 1080 and an i7-4790k, and I got stable performance albeit not exceptional on the high preset. For me I am fine if a game runs at 30 as long as it is stable, and Space Marine 2 was, depending on level, either running at stable 30, stable 45, stable 60 or unstable 20-30. The 20-30 range being in some of the later where the game is really flexing it's muscle in terms of scale and the number of effects on screen. As for all the stuff with the Epic integration? Quite literally you accept the EULA and that's it. It has no other impact on your gameplay. I find complaints around this sort of stuff to be valid, if exaggerated. It is okay to be upset that this is "forced" upon you, but I do not think it warrants leaving a negative review for the game, personally. Story? This feels like it could've been a 40k novel. I say that with significant praise, compared to the first game the stakes are higher, the characters are better, and it just feels like a part of actual canon now. I am incredibly satisfied, and depending on how the game develops in the next few years, it might firmly take the spot for "My personal favorite 40k game", as it is now, however? Firmly top 3.Suffice to say, I strongly recommend this game, I will be diving into the multiplayer and co-op components in the next few days, and if there is anything to add or detract from this review, expect addenda :) If no addenda are found on this review, my stance holds firm.

review: 2022 I only played through about half the campaigns but here's a small list of what I noticed1.) I can run units through other units with almost no resistance, this means there's effectively there is no front line.2.) Ogres can't be knocked over, it's weird watching one tank a cannon shot in the face and immediately shoot back.Cathy have a unique stance. This drastically reduces unit performance so a major mechanic of the faction makes them worse if you decide to use it.3.) ranged units have targeting issues. They will, seemingly without reason, be unable to fire at targets that are within plain view of them4.) ranged units will sometimes decide to melee charge another unit instead when you order them to shoot them5.) large drops in performance once the portals open up on the campaign map.6.) certain quest battles will crash the game when you try them for the first time7.) Calvary charges usually annihilate unit formation with no real logic to it. The heavily armored cav charges will do less than they did in warhammer 2 to regular empire swordsman but a charge from light cav will send chaos knights units flying through the air for several seconds and completely scatter the formation? Something is clearly wrong with the way mass is being calculated.8.)spells are out of balance. I noticed spells that were ok from previous titles are wiping out units or destroying the formation now. (looking at you pendulum)9.) the cutscenes are all copy and paste. it's jarring watching the same cut scene for different faction leaders. 10.) the chaos invasion makes so that occasionally ill be fighting 6 or 7 armies at a single town in one turn and then I'll have to fight 3 or 4 more the next turn with the battered army. it's incredibly tedious.11.) dealing with corruption is a chore, there's 7 or 8 different types, it's ridiculous Wait to see if the modding community is able to fix these issues. if not then don't pay more than dlc price for the game because that's what it feels like. A dlc campaign for 2

review: So far I love everything about this game. From the story, visuals, gameplay... it's a beautiful game about chinese mythology and a rare gem of 2024. The world and visuals are stunning, although exploration is linear I want to see everything this game has to offer. This is also the first game where I chose not to play in default english, as it sounds so much better in original voice (chinese) and it makes for a more unique experience.Combat is souls inspired, but difficulty is very forgiving. There is no block/parry button, you only have to dodge attacks at the right time. Also at dying you won't loose anything, but enemies will respawn on dying and resting. This game is not hard as souls-like so noob casuals like me can give this a try. However it can still be challenging and some bosses will make you die over and over again. You can't rush in and mash buttons expecting not to die in a few hits. With that said you may have to adapt your skill points, thankfully respec doesn't cost anything so you have all the freedom to try out different abilities/playstyle.To summarize, it's an amazing singleplayer game with all the right components- interesting story, great gameplay, amazing visuals and sound effects. Optimization is very good. I can play it on my old pc (i5-7500 and GTX 1060) with a bit of tweaking. Great purchase, fantastic game! 10/10

review: The game is Warhammer 40K through and through. Grim, Dark and gritty.The story is good and introduces you to why Titus got turned into a Primaris well.For the obvious culture war question: No, it is not "woke".Combat is violent and satisfying. A similar experience to what I recently had with Batman Arkham Knight. It is challenging.(Countering, dodging and learning patterns etc, but it is more simplified here).When you play as Titus you FEEL like a Space Marine. The power of the melee attacks, ripping enemies limb from limb. The shaking footsteps where you can 'feel' the weight behind every step. The thunderous boom as so much armour, meat, bone and muscle hits the ground after jumping down a ledge.Started the game on hardest difficulty, and it is very challenging. Still determining if it will be possible to finish playing solo with bots. Edit: Seems possible, but is very challenging. Would only suggest "Angel of death" difficulty for the most dedicated players.Shooting is also satisfying, but can't be completely relied on, engaging in melee is nearly mandatory once swarms close in.Visuals are very impressive and faithfully 40K.Sounds are all great and when involved in fighting give you the feeling you are in a battle.Music is dark and 100% fits 40K theme. The main theme when the game starts actually sent chills down my back. (Awe inspiring).After a quick look, operations and Endless War mode will provide plenty of replay opportunity.Edit: Operations is thoroughly enjoyable. Levelling up is fun and very satisfying to become more powerful with more perks, better weapons and the armour skins are beautiful. The artists REALLY put effort into them!On technical and performance, the game is running beautifully. RTX 3060, I7-10700K, 32GB RAM, SSD, Windows 11. Ultra settings, native resolution @ 1080P with TAA gives 40-60 frames. Lowest frames I've experienced so far are 30 in graphically intensive portions. (Considering my hardware is not high end, the performance was surprising to me, it shows the game is well optimised in my opinion). The game practically oozes all the effort and work the developers put into the game and definitely worth any 40K fan's attention.Some are saying it has Epic. The game makes use of Epic online services. (Not an app, just core components that allow crossplay between Steam and Epic as well as the needed files for Easy Anti Cheat. No Epic account was required when I started the game and none created that I am aware of).A couple of technical issues I can't figure out, sometimes voice lines are normal, then barely audible (with subtitles it isn't too much of a problem, but if playing without them you strain to hear them.)The most glaring problem is that the so called anti-cheat is doing nothing to keep cheaters out from ruining the game for others. That alone is enough to spoil the entire experience in PVE and PVP.Couldn't join a friend in campaign and still looking for a solution. (Will update review if I find one or find the cause). Edit: I was able to join friends today with a few retry attempts, but connecting isn't reliable and sometimes doesn't work.Edit: No crashes or glitches thus far with exception that sometimes a save seems to glitch out and you restart a checkpoint with lower ammo, different primary than the one you chose along the mission, meds and health than you had when you reached the checkpoint. (This happened to me on "Severance" mission when activating generators with Ripper swarms, Gaunts, Zoanthropes and Warriors mobbing me. Unknown what exactly happens to cause the glitch.

review: 2022 (Just to lay down my bonafides, since every negative review here is instantly spammed with 'git gud' or some cringe 2011-type beat: I've 100%ed every Dark Souls game. I've done speedruns, challenge runs, the whole lot. When I call things in Elden Ring hard, it is NOT for lack of experience.)Elden Ring has a lot of minor flaws (sparse armor early game, some jank w/ teleporting field bosses, boring crafting, boring catacombs, the hundreds of spirits and flowers I will NEVER use), but I can basically forgive all of those, because the game (at the start) is honestly incredible.However... about halfway through, the development budget totally falls out, and every area is now a ten-mile corridor full of enemies that can 2-shot you *alone*. The placement feels almost random at times, and it gets tilting fast. There is an entire lategame subcontinent with *three* graces. That means, if you die to any of the 2-shotting wolves or patrolling archer hordes, you have to cross the entire thing again. The two areas after that are nearly as bad, to the point that sprinting through is the only viable option.Once again, I can totally forgive some bad levels! Every game has some... but the larger bosses feel like pulling teeth.Trying to beat every shardbearer (major boss), you'll find at least two that are literally unplayable. One early game that is easily cheesable, Starscourge Radahn, and one lategame that is entirely unforgiveable, Malenia, Blade of Miquella. The latter has an attack that is almost entirely undodgeable, with a half-second tell that only helps if you're 30 feet away, and takes me from 1500 to 0 in a second. After all the shardbearers, you get the semifinal boss, a damage sponge who can 1 or 2-shot with every attack, who has an entire phase where every attack is a room-filling AOE, and who then phases into a grab machine that will instakill you with its comical grab hitboxes and 12-attack combos.If you can beat the AOE/Grab-machine, you get the honor of fighting the final boss... which has a fun-if-unfairish first phase, followed up by a ridiculous final phase full of camera-breaking nonsense and a very childlike idea of "Cool Final Boss", which singlehandedly ruined my belief that the writers had ANY plan for this endgame. Like, we had a cool final boss in phase one with Radagon, but they got swapped for ~the idea of the elden ring~ like a ridiculous Soul of Cinder parody. Once the comical, humiliating damage sponge is taken care of, you get your pick of ending! There are effectively two, with one obviously bad third choice where you literally burn the entire world, because why not, and overall, we leave with very little idea what any of this was about, what our ending choice even means for the world, or what we've really done in the first place. Yay! Game done! After 90 hours, I feel totally numb and ambivalent to this!There are a lot more things to talk about, like how finnicky quests become with an open world, but ♥♥♥♥. I think the worst thing I can say is that I spent all of Elden Ring planning new runs and build ideas, and now that I've beaten it... I just feel tired... and let down. (But the OST does 100% slap, and I do love Torrent, as well as a lot of the NPCs. 100% A+ for them, you can hug a woman, which is more than I can say about my love life)---EDIT: There is actually precisely ONE thing from the comments I'd like to add to this review. If you see anyone saying Elden Ring has 'six' endings, let me break them down for you.There is the basic ending. There is the true-ish ending. There is a bad ending. Then, there are three more endings. These are all the basic ending with a color filter over the cutscene and a single word of dialogue changed. Nothing new is added, and they amount to: Become god, become god but bad (grey), become god but VERY bad (red), and become god but catholic. These feel like extremely late additions, and they only highlight how vapid the difference in non-apocalyptic endings really is. They're meaningless enough that Elden Ring *basically* only has three endings.Also, I only learned after writing this that the game features a field boss who is literally the first shardbearer! The dude from all the trailers just... shows up in the field with a different name, and you fight him again. Elden Ring's copypasting problem is seriously everpresent, and I've not touched on it as much as it deserves, especially considering how mandatory catacombs are to the game. It's fun for one run, but by the second playthrough, I'd really prefer if spirit tuning components were just distributed throughout the fun parts of the game.

review: So Space Marine 2 here we are. First things first: If you aren't a huge 40k fan wait for a steep discount. The best part of this game is the art direction and its simply superb. They managed to capture the 40k atmosphere for the most part.The bad parts: The gunplay suck You are a primaris marine and cant hit the broad side of a barn with your bolter Your bolter sucks. (it looks like it explodes but it just staggers most enemies and creates a small splash effect) Your bolter sucks. You barely have any ammunition. The melee sucks. (4 basic weapons which are boring to use) The moment to moment gameplay sucks (Every mission is the same. You go into an area, a swarm spawns, you kill the swarm then you destroy a wall/lower a bridge/open a door/switch a lever. In almost 6 hours of gameplay there was nothing else to do inside the missions. The story is barebones and ♥♥♥♥. And the icing on the cake is that there a million lore errors. (Negro Ultramarines, incorrect Astartes greetings, wrong bolters, etc)Finally the controls are setup for console peasants. Also the game has a greedy live service model and comes with a day 1 season pass. Tldr; Wait until you get it for 10-15€ or from an "alternative" source.

review: Game is good, but has room for some extra polish or optimizations.The story is a good power trip where the content feels challenging but you have the tools to do it. Some of the gimmicks wear themselves thin, even more so as a solo or duo where you have to trust the bots to deal the main damage over yourself (such as ripper segments). Thankfully these segments are few and far between. PVP is also fun with 6v6 matches and is enjoyable even though the modes are pretty basic.My biggest complaint right now is the fact PVP map pool is only 3 maps. The road map indicates a new map in 2025 but that means 3+ months grinding on only the current small pool. This and the slow pace of unlocking gear in PVP, I can see being a point of burnout for people. Also PVP matches really need to shuffle teams as two three mans can queue snipe each other to doom stack a lobby. Just general flow around menuing for PVP is also kinda clunky between the amount of load screens and waiting. For instance you can't edit your loadout in match, you must finish your game, then load into your battle barge, go to the armory and wait for the robo boy to slowly come down all while a timer ticks for the next match. To the point why even bother loading into the barge when all of this could just be menus you can flip through post match. And on the point of load screens god they are a pain. I know I don't have the best computer but even my friends are faster rigs have long load times just getting in and connected

Better graphics and game-play, more weapons and customisation options, and most importantly an implemented ranked game-mode and ranking system.

review: 2023 Elden Ring is a delicious late afternoon wine and cracker platter under a sweltering sun, cooled by a spring breeze and relaxing backyard music. The wine, the good of Elden Ring, it is intoxicating, addicting, aromatic and fruity, yet aged to perfection. The cracker, the difficulty, it is hard, rough, gritty and perhaps a little tough to bite through. Heck, some of the crackers on this platter are so stiff and unpalatable it could be hardtack. But there is no such crunch in Elden Ring, and these crackers, that cannot be overcome by lathering on a thick layer of cream cheese. How much cheese you apply to your cracker is up to you, but what you'll come to learn is that there is no right way to enjoy this wine. We all have our own idea of how much cheese we like. Some enjoy so much cheese that the cracker becomes obscured, perhaps there might as well not be any. Some enjoy their crackers dry, to compliment the complex blend of the wine as was intended.In either case, you will find how you like your game and enjoy it.

review: 2023 My biggest issues are:- Game feel left alone as a cash cow. It started as a succesor of Warhammer 2 which was a great game, and outside of having more content is a strict downgrade on many levels.- Game is not being fixed outside of DLC patches, and even new content comes with unpolished and buggy stuff, that then never gets addressed. And this bugs are major ones, like whole systems (which in warhammer 2 worked!) being unplayable for months.- Sieges are total garbage, even compared to warhammer 2, where they were the biggest issue of a game (and game big selling point was reworked sieges...).- But probably biggest one for me, campaign feeling got worse. AI is completely incompetent in doing anything (which is strange, because coding is based on a previous game which was way better), it runs from you, deplete miserable forces and hardly prove a challenge. It gives an awful experience, where in like 5-10 turns I can steamroll every campaign without any thought, autoresolving almost every battle.It can provide some fun, but you will get way more from just a warhammer 2, can't recommend it, and considering rumors around this game it can only get worse.

review: Depending on what you want from the game it's either for you or not.If you are looking for a game with the elements of a Mass Effect or maybe Rogue Trader in it's story then this ain't for you, it's a game for the people who want the old games from 2010 back, the action based third person shooter with blood and gore. People who enjoyed the first game or even GOW, you will have a blast with the different executions, the gunplay and the overall presentation of Space Marine 2.It feels really good to just sit down, join some friends and blast your way through a tyranid horde and watching your custom made Space Marine cutting a Warrior in halve.The campaign itself was for my taste long enough, it had it's amazing moments with certain twists and expecially the presentation of the battlefield, how the skybox looks and the complete level design is something from another world.You get sucked into the world of 40k in a blink of an eye, even the intro video was the sweetest eye candy I had this year but it doesn't just end there, it goes on with massive scaled battles taking place in the background and the ambiente just fits so well into this setting, so fluent and yet so sharp.The Operations are not exactly what I expected, I do love the different perspective on the levels with the view of the other teams and what they did, it gives another nice inside on how the war against the xenos is fought.But I would have loved a similiar kind of PVE gameplay like in Darktide, might just be me but it would suit the game more if they'd add something like that, not as repetitive like Darktide but inspired by it to say the least.The classes all feel unique in their own way with how they play and feel like.Customisation on the other hand is done right with the player having to play the game and not just buying in on it, I get that people like to get the easy way sometimes but honestly, that's the way I like it with Space Marine 2.Don't get me wrong, I really love the fan service of most Warhammer games and I believe this game will do just as good as a Halo Reach in terms of said Fan Service.The multiplayer although needs a lot of work, unfortunately there is no true customisation for the Chaos Marines which makes me quite sad, I'd love to have a full World Eater set with all the different parts of armour and insignias there are but we just have to wait for that.Balance so far is ok-ish if you know how to counter f.e. a heavy, you won't have a big of a problem dealing with them but classes like the Assault who are just a flying target with no really prowess to themself or the Vanguard who has no real chance on surviving a encounter with a tactical is something they need to work on.Especially the Vanguard would benefit from one armour slot more or maybe a better evasion during fights, I know it's a light class but having a sniper ripping you apart with his pistol because your hook is taking a bit to long to shoot you towards him is frustrating, might just be me but that's my opinion on it.The game shows great promise in becoming a true sucessor to the first part and as of now it is a really good, if not even the best Warhammer game out there at this very moment, maybe Darktide is a bit better but that's just me, I love both of the games.Space Marine 2 is a game which gives the players what they want, it's really refreshing to have a game like this combating modern gaming and showing us that there are still people out there who care about a franchise this big.There are some technical issues I don't like that much like latency and the game not closing right, or just randomly closing the lobby in PVE and refusing to start a mission even tho everybody is present in the ready zone but honestly, it's not even fully released yet and we all payed to get our hands earlier on the game so I think it's something you can excuse as of now.If the stability of the game will be improved or not is up to the Devs and I hope they will take their time with the new DLCs, they already did really good on WWZ but they can do even better with this one.Can't wait to see this game becoming GOTY.That's all from me, if there is anything you dislike or think I missed please just leave a comment on this review.Stay well everyone

review: 2022 NOTE: This game needs a pretty beefy pc at least in its current state, maybe once they optimize it better it will not stutter for those that have a gpu bellow the 2000 series. Review:Besides some bad PC optimization, some stutters which seem to only occur at the worst possible moment, this game is what I would consider a beautiful byproduct had Zelda Breath of the Wild and Dark Souls 3 spent a night in an Inn while it was raining outside. It has both open world, and in this case not the empty EA/Ubisoft kind where exploring will actually reward you. I cant count the number of times I have been to some god forsaken corner of the map and I actually found some hidden loot there. Meanwhile, it also presents the players will challenges like the bosses are significantly harder than those in Dark Souls 3. I am as of right now only 20hrs in and the ending is nowhere in site, honestly I don't even want to see it. This game has been hands down the best game I have played in the last five years. Do note I am a MASSIVE Dark Souls fan boy so I may have some bias because of that. I would definitely recommend it for anyone who love DS and exploration game!

review: 2022 It pains me to write this given all the hype behind this long awaited capstone title. I will say fully upfront I preordered and that burden to bear is mine. All the marketing was nice and shiny and it appeared CA was hitting a lot of notes towards genuinely improving upon the last two games. Well, the game drops, the NDAs are lifted and it quickly became apparent to many that apart from the ICONIC Creative Assembly launch bugs, the main campaign was and is at the time of writing this review: not fun. If you played Warhammer II you're getting the vortex campaign but worse. More accurately, it's like playing the Tomb Kings campaign but every Book of Nagash you get makes the game artificially harder, gives you no rewards, you can only access said books with your Legendary Lord and the location in which you retrieve the books gives you crippling debuffs and forces your lord to sit in a capital effectively removing one of your armies from play from an indeterminate amount of time. All this with the game expecting you to complete the objectives at a breakneck pace against grossly anti-player biased cheating AI. Oh, and you're discouraged from expanding your territory more than perhaps any other Total War game.A patch is supposedly coming in a few weeks to address some of these issues but it will not mechanically make the game more enjoyable. Take the realm of Tzeentch as an example for this section. The minimum time a player can complete this realm is I think 5 turns. If the AI makes it into the realm before you, forget it the objective is just lost. The AI is hard coded to always complete this section in the absolute minimum amount of time (and sometimes even less than that. In one of my campaigns the enemy completed this section in only two turns (this goes back to the breakneck pace I mentioned above.)Sieges:Another sly trick of the marketing campaign I was convinced would have been improved, there are simply far too many issues with AI pathing, terrain, unit responsiveness, and the so called "defenses" you are provided in the form of towers. A good 40% of these towers I have built have erected right up against a piece of terrain, or a piece of the fortress wall. This means one side of the tower is completely useless while the other only has a sliver of an angle from which to fire. These problems are all interwoven as the cheating AI pays no supply cost to build towers and those towers build instantly. This is not the case for the player and makes any sort of tactical play by destroying key defensive structures totally bunk. Optimization/Bugs/Crashes:While I myself cannot speak to anything negative with regards to the optimization and performance on my machine. I did experience one crash at my end turn but other than that I have been running fine. I can even alt-tab without issue. What is odd is that rigs much beefier than mine seem to be disproportionately affected by this and is of course unacceptable. However, we still are plagued with the gate bug, cavalry charges not feeling powerful, Slaanesh chariots just not working correctly at all, and new ones that have been introduced in the Chaos maps. Units can disappear and get stuck under an invisible lava bridge in Khorne settlements and so on. A couple of snow maps have had some weird flickering issues and are so bright it can irritate your eyes.Multiplayer:Just wanted to add a small section here for what is a small section of the player base. I enjoyed occasionally hopping into some quick battles back in Warhammer II. For whatever reason Creative Assembly has decided to push, and I do mean, push, a new multiplayer domination game mode with a few RTT style capture points, resources, etc. I don't hate the mode but it was pushed to the point where a player could no longer use the quick search feature for land battles. You could only play in this new ranked game mode unless of course you set up private lobbies. Lobbies that were total broken the first week or two of the game's release. Good luck finding a match when any tweaks to your search filters caused the lobbies to dissappear. Going forward there absolutely needs to be a quick match feature for both domination AND land battles. I want to enjoy the multiplayer from time to time but Creative Assembly has stripped away more choice from the player then haughtily assured them this is what they want.Closing:There is a lot here that would make Total War: Warhammer 3 a good game. There are genuinely good quality of life changes to diplomacy, the new factions are fun and all have a different play style to them. The sensation you get when large armies are clashing with one another can still be achieved from time to time. The daemon prince customization has a lot of potential for future content but in his current state he is too weak. I have no idea what they were thinking recommending it as a first campaign (other than to show off the mechanics of it) because you have way too many enemies to deal with. I'm saying this as someone with `1600 hours in Warhammer II and not as someone who is playing their first Total War title. The prologue campaign is not only an excellent tutorial for completely new players but it also proves Creative Assembly can competently make a gripping, narrative Total War campaign. I do take issue with everything in the UI just being a shade of red while at the same time getting rid of a lot of the flavorful art that gave the menus some life. They just went for a very rigid, efficient approach and I can't fault them for that. It's just too red. The new traits for defeating lords are totally lackluster. Auto resolve is just a craps shoot. Unit mass has been ruined entirely. This is at its core an open beta you are expected to pay $60 for and I think even suggesting it's a Warhammer II expansion is a little too generous. Creative Assembly had the makings for one of the best releases this year right there in their laps and in their arrogance they shelled out all these keys for these influencers so called only to ignore all feedback and criticism prior to launch. I won't even touch the debacle in China or the need to maintain a T rating to reach a broader market. We can have the land of the blood good, rivers of blood, fountains of blood, blood daemons, everything but the combatants are allowed to bleed. And don't get me started on the titty daemons. Now that the players have fallen off dramatically we are finally getting a patch roughly a month and a half after launch. A patch that will fix and or add things that should have been in day one. Thus is the state of modern gaming. I preordered this game while cynically knowing in the back of my mind some of what I was getting in to. Are you brand new to the series? Do not get this game at all lest Creative Assembly somehow step down from their pedestal and offer Immortal Empires to everyone who owns game 3 regardless of the other two. Be warned now that the complete Total War: Warhammer experience will run you over $250 (although sales are prevalent) not counting the future DLC planned for this game (assuming they're still willing to give this the TLC it needs and not ax it like Three Kingdoms when the going got tough.) Fan of the Warhammer series and own the other two titles? Your best bet is waiting for Immortal Empires which could be...June? A lot needs to happen in the meantime. It's very obvious none of the important bits were playtested. I will be continuing to play with an edited script to stop the main drive of the campaign, my own little sandbox if you will. But it shouldn't have to be this way. You could say I'm a little disappointed. Thank you for reading if you made it this far.

review: Honestly the game is rather disappointing - seeing people praise it so much makes me worried the devs will get complacent with what little has been given out.You might see most reviews and think 'Oh, they're just upset there are server issues, the game will definitely be fine on launch!' and you would be right in that regard, but that isn't the main issue.Some good things first: 1. Looks beautiful. Probably has never been a better time to turn tyranids and traitors into mist (or dust also in the latter's case).2. Story is short and sweet. It won't change your life, but it is a fun experience.3. Customisation is solid.Now my main complaints:1. Crazy lack of unit variety. With a species like the tyranids you would think such a diversity of monsters are trying to kill you, but no, 60% of the time it is hormagaunts, 20% termagants, 15% tyranid warriors, and 5% everything else, of which stronger enemies such as the carnifex or neurothrope do not appear asides from very specific mission encounters. Hell, you even have gargoyles attack environmental things in the story and you have to stop them, but they never attack you??For chaos it is little better. 30% some weak chaos cultists who can be killed by sprinting through them(lol), 30% tzaangors(small bird demons with swords and shields), 30% chaos space marines, and 10% a terminator or lesser sorcerer.These issues are made worse with the secondary issue.2. A lack of operations. As it stands there are six operations to enjoy the classes and customisation with. It frankly gets old, very very very quickly. This is mostly due to these operations being story related missions, as opposed to something like Helldivers where you go to an invaded planet with randomly generated environments with side objectives; you are in effect replaying story missions. This is also worse if you have a preference for faction fighting - there are in effect three and a half tyranid operations, and two and a half chaos operations.Putting these two things together and the game feels like to me there is nothing more to do. The roadmap has not got me feeling too optimistic. This year we will get a 'new enemy', and next year (based off of wording) two more? There won't even be a horde mode until late next year. There will be a few more missions before the end of the this year, and one next year???? Killing the same three things per faction 90% of the time is insanely boring, even if the tyranid warriors and chaos space marines have some slight variation, it is far too similar to not feel you are fighting the same thing; the basic formula you will encounter is you are dealing with 25 hormagaunts stabbing you, 5 termagants shooting at you and one tyranid warrior shooting or stabbing you and that is basically it for your tyranid experience for however long you want to play this game.Smaller issues to just throw out. You do not feel like a space marine - you are constantly taking a crap load of damage, you are slow and sluggish. Higher difficulties make melee classes (of which three almost strictly are, and one in the middle) feel awful. Executions feel like they get old quickly, you feel like they are something you do to desperately get armour back and buy you a few seconds rather than look cool. Doesn't feel like you are fighting a horde - they give you this image as three space marines making a last stand against 1000 tyranids, yeah, no, hardly. Maybe 75 tops at once divided by three people; the other 925 are waiting for you to kill the other ones before all taking fair turns. Guns are not accurate, especially hip-fire, as if these space marines of all people have such atrocious aim. I'm sorry, but for the wait and the hype this is shockingly lacking. I really thought this would be the new addiction for a few months, but it really won't be. I remember everyone said this will kill Helldivers, and it might just do so, but honestly Helldivers very sadly blows this out of the water as it currently stands and that is the opposite of what I was hoping for. I really hope they try to make this better, but I reckon there will be little done to add content with the glazing this game is seeing.This game is for you if you are painfully starved of 40K content(please play Rogue Trader, DOW, or Darktide instead), are someone who does not care this game will be a very short ride, or is someone who is often too busy to play enough where the little amount of content will not be felt more greatly.I know it is getting a lot of positive attention, I bought into the hype myself, but it is frankly not even remotely worth it in this state; I would have been happy to wait another year than get this half-baked experience.

review: 2022 At this moment in time I would really, really like to be able to recommend this game. I enjoy the game-play mechanics, especially some of the new ones added in this rendition, I adore the Warhammer universe and have loved every previous instalment of this series. However with the current performance issues of this title, I'm simply unable to do so.The Total war games are games I've grown up playing and have been playing for many, many years now, hell I've still got my original CD copies of Rome, Empire, Medieval II etc. and I believe they are among the greatest games to have been made. However, most of these when they launched would at the very least function to a playable standard on most PC's with a good range of function as was considered for the time. This however does not. The optimisation of this game is horrendous, I don't know if it's down to a poor engine that is dated, running with sub-par code, or possibly, most likely, Denuvo. I have tried all the fixes, tweaked all the settings, and cannot see it changing for a considerable time.If a time comes when they have fixed the performance, balanced out some of the game mechanics between the different factions, then I will change my review. But until that time I cannot recommend that you pick up this game, pick up the older games and play them to death, they are amazing. But this one definitely has missed the mark for at least my personal expectation.

review: 2022 I am unhappy with Warhammer III. It pales in comparison to Warhammer II. I continue to play WH3 in hopes that it will continue to get massive AI changes. Immortal Empires campaign is one of the main reasons I play still, with all the new races, factions, and landmarks. But the AI feels completely outmatched by turn 30-40 even on Legendary. I don't need the AI to have massive cheats and bonuses, but the game needs to have the AI be able to confederate territories far more often. Also the diplomacy in Warhammer is one of the most under utilized. CA needs to seriously take a look at how other games are handling interaction in Grand Strategy Campaign Turn Based Games. Some factions have no economy whatsoever, and its not that, that makes it far more challenging, but just irritating. I don't want to play Khorne or Kislev and just get beat by another race cause they can actually afford military power and I cannot. Confederations feel harder than ever with no longer being able to buy your allies, like you could in WH2, and I am in no way saying that was immersive and fun. But at a certain point if I have 400 relations with an ally, and I am strength rank 1-3 it seems silly that a 2 province Dark Elf faction wouldn't confederate with me. Diplomacy as a whole is missing so many additional options. You can barely even vassalize in this game or perform certain diplomacy options, even though they are available, but almost always unobtainable, therefore redundant.There's a lot of battle changes the devs have made to WH3 from 2, some have been for the better - buffing melee infantry, buffing melee cavalry, magic can now "target" single targets so its not just an absolute waste of winds. However minor settlement battles can be a little irritable, thankfully they recently nerfed towers. But they removed walling minor settlements, which makes the entire defensive tab irrelevant. There's also a lot of building chains in general for multiple races that feel like they do almost nothing, or are far too niche to even bother having. The map is incomplete and still feels to small. This is the end game of the trilogy. And even though they greatly increased our map, its almost that we don't need to keep pushing the borders, but breaking up the lands that we already have. I don't need to walk 3 turns every time to get to a new town or city. There's so many areas in the Warhammer Lore, and we are missing and it feels like such an easy opportunity that is lost on us. The Druchii Northern Mountains, The Dwarven Chasms in the World's Edge Conglomeration (Karak Drazh, Karaz-a-Karak, Karak Eight Peaks (also wth happened to K8P, now it doesn't even remotely look like it should)), The Empire itself - I feel this is going to be greatly expanded in the new update, but Bretonnia, Norscan Peninsula, Kislev, The Southern Realms, Lustria, Araby, have so much more room for development and map changes and it could make little towns feel like a whole new faction. Eveything feels far too condensed. Warhammer II always felt at the right pace, and the AI could actually form an Enemy/Rival Empire and be an actual global threat, now there's just a bunch of squabbling major races that can't manage their territories. Also 'Recruit Defeated Legendary Lords' should be apart of the game, its silly that it still hasn't happened. It would allow races to actually begin to steamroll, which you need because there's such a lack of any endgame big bad, not even the Ultimate Crisis Mode on max can really kill you unless it's super early. I feel this game has the potential to be great however right now I find myself disinterested and salty over a truly failed DLC launch with SOC. $25 for a half-assed DLC, and pushing back content release dates almost 3-6 months behind schedule now. If I see another $25 DLC and its even close to as less than the now fully released SOC, I will be leaving this review. Until then I hope I get to change this mentality for the better in the future.

review: 2023 Я помню, как Valve объявила о начале beta-тестирования данного продукта. Тогда все хотели заполучить злополучную «каэску», увидеть и почувствовать на себе все изменения, которых не мало. Некоторые платили весьма кругленькие суммы, кто-то неделями сидел на Steam Gifts и все для того, чтобы получить игру, на которую возложено много надежд и множество ожиданий. Однако все это было уже после того как Valve сделала анкету, пройдя которую можно было получить игру, но мне было не понятно (да и сейчас тоже непонятно) по каким критериям выбирают бета-тестеров (сам я игру получил через 4 месяца после прохождения анкеты). И те, кто всё же получал CS:GO поначалу были очень довольны. Так же нельзя не упомянуть тот факт, что разрабатывали игру две компании: всем известная Valve и менее известная Hidden Path Entertainment.Valve и их новая Counter Strike: GO обещали порадовать всех: и фанатов CS: S, и тех, кто остался верен CS 1.6, и даже тех кто к «контре» так и не приобщился. Многих порадовало то, что в разработке принимала участие студия Barking Dog Studios, в своё время работавшая над CS 1.6.Безусловно, они заинтересовали тех, кто мало знаком (или незнаком вообще) с онлайн шутерами. Мнения остальных довольно контрастны. На мой взгляд, перед нами всё та же Counter Strike Source (как известно CS:GO использует именно движок Source, точнее последнюю его версию) только с измененной графикой, измененным видом меню и с чутка подкрученной баллистикой. И весьма сложно назвать возрождением Counter Strike, поскольку в CS: GO проглядываются черты не только Counter Strike, но и черты Call of Duty (что было замечено еще в первом тейлере), даже музыка в игре сильно напоминает музыку из Modern Warfare 3.И говоря о первом трейлере можно упомянуть, что многим не понравилось, как выглядят некоторые оружия (особенно гранаты), но уже на данный момент некоторые модельки потерпели изменения в лучшую, по моему мнению, сторону.Но все же игра доставляет удовольствие, и не из-за графики или изменённых карт, которые действительно впечатляют, а именно из-за геймплея. Геймплей, в свою очередь, почти не подвергся каким-либо изменениям. Он остался динамичным и воистину «каэсовским» (эдакая смесь CS 1.6 и CS:S). Все также перед нами стоит выбор за кого играть: за террористов или за контр-террористов.В общем и целом можно сказать, что на данной стадии Counter Strike Global Offensive выглядит довольно прилично, конечно есть недочеты, но все же не стоит забывать, что перед нами только Beta версия и все еще может измениться.Можно так же отметить несколько плюсов: расширенный арсенал оружия, улучшенная детализация оружия, возможность при смерти играть за бота, на серверах для баланса добавляются боты. Огромным плюсом, на мой взгляд, стало то, что оружие теперь имеет вес, т.е. с ножом бегаешь быстрее чем с винтовкой. Так же появилась поддержка DirectX 11.Про минусы, я думаю, будет глупо писать, ибо это только beta версия и все еще может измениться.

review: 2023 I have many hundreds of hours in TWW I & II, and love the series. TWW 3 launched in a buggy unplayable state and I assumed they would eventually patch it into a reasonable gaming experience. It's just never been in a fun and playable state and I find the demons gross. It says a lot when I'm more interested in watching matches on youtube than I am in actually playing TWW III, so y'all have fun. This is not a quality product and I recommend doing just about anything else with your time. I'm out.

review: 2020 After 8 years playing it, I didn't improve my skills in-game.However, I learned new language skills: now I can curse in Russian and Brazilian Portuguese.Also, my tolerance level to guttural screams and loud sounds was increased.Now I can bear the crying of my children for longer and I can make them feel better by singing sweet traditional songs from other cultures, such as Очи чёрные (Dark Eyes) or Garota de Ipanema (The Girl from Ipanema).In conclusion, Counter Strike transformed me into a better father and a better person, in addition to making me more patient, tolerant to hateful people and more trained in languages and cultures.Better than any psychiatric therapy. 10/10

review: This game came as a bit of a surprise, since the first instalment of the series was a moderately successful title that left fans wanting more. Now, 13 entire years later, we get a sequel that turbo boosts the concept of the original in every way imaginable.You still play as Titus, but now you have a squad that follows you in every mission, and the main enemy for the first half of the game are Tyranids.Said Tyranids have some of the best dynamic swarm movement I've ever seen in a videogame thanks to the dev's experience with similar mechanics on games like World War Z.They can break off into clusters, pile on top of walls and generally act like a real horde, not a pre-scripted bot puppet.Graphically, the game is truly impressive, perhaps one of the best I've ever seen. I never tire of looking at the vast, grandiose cities going down in flames as battles rage on in the distance, with swarms of aliens descending from the skies while battleships fire at them. The design of the marines and maps is also spot-on, Warhammer fans (myself included) will rejoice at the small details on every character and building model. Of course, such heavy graphical fidelity comes at the price of performance, and the game does need a beast of a PC to run: with an RTX4070 ti, I could only manage 60-90 FPS at 1440p with everything maxed, with dips below 60 in extremely messy scenes. Still, DLSS did its job (I'm sure that without it, performance would be even worse) and the game hasn't crashed in over 12 hours of play so far.Sound design is also good, with special mention going to the weapon effects: one can only describe them as...meaty.Now, to the main point: the gameplay is limited, but enjoyable. What I mean by this is that you won't get any complex plots, open maps and huge skill trees here: story mode is almost completely linear, point A to point B, kill enemies, cutscene, repeat. You have some loadout options, but overall it's really not worth playing more than once.However, it is very fun, and it doesn't overstay its welcome at an average duration of 8-10 hours (side missions excluded).The melee combat didn't click much for me personally, with an awkward parry system and combos that can be performed with only one button. The ranged, third-person shooting is very satisfying though.After you're done with the story, you have two main modes to discover: the side missions that are heavily coop-focused and have their own class and progression system, and the PvP multiplayer.Said missions are much more challenging than the main story and require you to use your combined abilities and weapons to succeed, while offering weapon leveling, special abilities, small skill trees and marine customization options.The PvP is serviceable, offering the usual modes ones would expect (capture point, team death match etc.) while including a modified version of the skill trees used in the other mode. It runs much better performance-wise (120 FPS) and it feels alright, not exactly an afterthought but certainly not the mode the devs have put the most work on. For example, they could have added extra features like vehicles, turrets, abilities unique to each faction or even the ability to control Tyranids ala Left 4 Dead to make it more exciting.Most of the criticism I can throw at this game is simply my wish for more of it: more missions, more weapons, more classes and definitely more factions. Happily, the devs have promised exactly that with the roadmap: we'll get further updates along the way, for free (with a paid cosmetic option) and a very likely expansion in the future, as the ending of the main story hints at more adventures.Given the commercial success of the title, I'm sure we'll get all of that and more.For the Emperor!

review: Regrettably i am leaving a negative review pointing out the serious shortcomings of Space Marine 2 as a veteran Vermintide/Darktide player who loves 40k lore.- During the first launch of the game, Epic games online components are installed automatically without a prompt screen. I do not want it in my computer. You have to go through loops to uninstall it. There is a reason why i am using steam and steam only and i want the developers to respect it. - When compared with Darktide, Dawn of War series and especially Mechanicus, Space Marine 2 has the weakest music OST. Looks like it was not even at top ten of the priority list during development.- As a cheap attempt, the game is trying to draw more attention by Twitch drops.- Very terrible companion ai. One of the worst i have seen for years. They do not use their ranged weapons in most cases and run gret distances to melee an enemy regarless of the class. And they very rarely execute a stunned elite enemy who is only two feet away from them. Such a shame. - No FOV slider.- Holding buttons to activate the abilities, instead of hitting them, is a terrible design choice.- Throwing a frag grenade takes two seconds, activating cloak takes another 2.5 seconds. Character gets hit during uncancellable animations. Every movement and ability use feels unresponsive and stiff during the campaign and multiplayer. Runningg gets interrupted for no reason even if you are holding shift and not even hit by anything. - Uncancellable dodge, roll over and similar animations are the primary reason why i keep dying. Controls feel very unresponsive.- Boss fights are almost identical. Area attacks such as some form of 3 round mortar shots, melee charge attacks, ranged attacks and one big 3-wave either green or purple wide area attack which can hit even behind cover is the same rinse and repeat mechanic for both tyranid and chaos bosses. - Melee combat is terribly designed. Interruptions are common and costs the player half of his health points.- Ranged weapons feel weak. An elite enemy (Not a boss or a lecter) takes 30 to 40 bolter rounds to put down. Crossing bone swords makes the enemy immune to ranged damage even if you hit the legs, head or spray it from sides. - The enemies i have mentioned above are bullet sponges but a hit from them take out half of your hp. - Crowd control options are limited to grenades. I suggest developers to play Vermintide and Dark Tide to see how it is perfected during many years. - There is a hideous terrible jetpack mission. I hated it.- Multiple 'Loading resources - loading logic' screens. - Entire multiplayer lobby system has to be redesigned. It is bad.- You cannot inject your allies with the stimpack you have in your inventory. - PVP section of the game is the worst. Very unbalanced. Is this game not beta-tested?- Cheaters are out there already. I have already witnessed speedhacks and maphacks.- Easy Anticheat is known as how 'Easy' it is to bypass it. A bad choice from the developers.- The number of the co-op missions is very few. These missions in general feel rushed, unfinished and exteremely repetitive with very little variation. Even the spawn locations are more or less the same.- Unlocking armor pieces or better versions of the same weapon is very grindy. This is how the game targets longevity.- The game becomes boring and repetitive very quickly. I do not expect it to have a long lifespan. - I was unable to pickup some medkits, ammo boxes or grenades even i had the inventory slot available. Pickup prompt was not there.- Ranged enemies shoot with 120% accuracy and every shot lands perfectly. - There is a shield or armor mechanic which recharges a specific amount with combo kills. This mechanic is not working as intended and definitely not user friendly.Cnclusion: 6/10. Wait for a discount or buy the cheapest package if you must. After the hype is dead, the game will no longer be played by most of us. I believe that Space Marine 2 would be a great game if it was released 10 years ago.

review: This game has the big awesome set pieces and aesthetic from the old school God of War games, the core gameplay of a Soul-like (albeit a tad more forgiving), really sick and fast paced Sekiro / Bloodborne combat, and every cool Kung Fu thing you can think of ever all mixed into one.Only a short bit in but this may be my GOTY. It also looks fantastic and runs surprisingly well (7800x3d + 3080 ti, getting 70-90 fps with RT off and everything on Very High).Very strong recommend out the gate. I have to stop playing and go to bed but I want more badly.edit: Played it a bit more at lunch and still enjoying it. The first boss f-ed me up a few times but overall this is easier than a FromSoft game. I also am really enjoying the quick spells / form changes, seems to add a nice diversity to the combat and strategy.

review: Black Myth Wukong is an absolute masterclass of a game. All the hype, all the praise, all the positive buzz surrounding this game...they're absolutely deserved and this is hands down, one of THE best games of this generation, not just this year. The combat, fluidity of animations, the level and boss design, the intricate level and environmental design, all the different characters and enemies, they're all very unique, varied and superbly crafted. When you take control of the Monkey King (Sun Wukong) you really feel the power behind that staff and every swing you make against your enemies. I won't spoil the details but the gameplay mechanic is very rich and varied and rewarding. There's a whole level up system that can be used to power up your abilities and spells which can be used in subsequent battles. This btw is not necessarily a souls-like game even though some mechanics are present there but the combat style is very fast and responsive. I'm only just scratching the surface of the game and trust me when I say, this is one of the best action RPG games I've ever played in a good while and easily among to very best the game industry has to offer. Easily a 10/10 for me. Well done Game Science for creating such a well-crafted masterpiece. You deserve all the success and praise.

review: 2022 Masterpiece of a game! PROS:-The story is masterfully told (not always through dialogue) and is FULL of lore. (Try looking at your surroundings and the scenery)-Open world is HUGE and convincing (And BEAUTIFUL!)-The Atmosphere is (with all fromsoft games) absolutely incredible-Exploration feels organic. When you find something cool, it actually feels like you discovered it. You aren't "hand-held" and guided to an objective by a quest marker on a minimap-The mechanics are well polished and varied-Weapons are plentiful and highly customizable-Ashes of war expand upon the weapon customization and are IMO the best addition to this game.-Invasions by other players are fair - giving the host an advantage (*Controversial opinion*)-Compatible with Steam cloud saves - A welcome change from DS3-You can jump! (I know, right?!)-I could go on...CONS:-FPS locked at 60-Made for controllers - mouse and keyboard can be bit awkward-Performance can be a bit stuttery at times, especially in large, open areas-Multiplayer is not the best:--Connection issues are common (Peer-to-peer sucks)--Severely limits mobility and restricts you to the specific area where summon takes place (Intended feature - Not necessarily a CON)YES, it's a hard game... NO, it shouldn't have an "easy mode"*** If you are having a hard time or getting one-shot by mobs/bosses... GO ELSEWHERE; maybe level up a bit. (Also, try putting points into vigor... How hard is that to figure out?) Vigor = life. This isn't dark souls. (As much as it feels like it is.) There is no need to bash your head against a brick wall (a.k.a. a boss) over and over again.GITTING GUD not required, but it IS HIGHLY advised...
